Basic healing and first aid
This page will deal with what beginners should know and first-aid techniques.

The very first thing all healers should be able to do is identify injury and disease. The way we do this is two fold, first by assessing the patient by asking questions. Example of assessing the patient is asking questions such as: How bad the pain is on a scale of 1-10. The second way to identify the injury or disease is by the senses. You should smell for blood or unusual odors. You should listen for labored breathing, wheezing, or oral complaints such as moaning and crying. You should look for bruising, abrasion, irritations, or open wounds. You should feel on and around the wound for further damage. After you have all available information you can make a diagnosis.
When in stressful situations it is critical to stay calm and to keep others around you calm. It is also important to make sure yourself, the patient, and bystanders are safe. A good way to accomplish this is to have bystanders 'help' you by having them do small errands for you. The sense of accomplishment will ease the worry of those close to the patient.
Important first-aid techniques:
Have a good supply of bandages on you at all times. This will ensure you are not scrambling to make them in critical situations. When wrapping a bandage around a body part make sure it is tight enough to stay on but not tight enough to cut off blood flow. A good way to ensure this is to stick two fingers between the bandage and the skin. Your fingers should fit easily. Stopping lose of blood is important, it should be one of the first things you tend to other then breathing and heart beat. Firm pressure on the wound will do the trick. When dealing with burns, water is the good solution. Wet bandages on burns will ensure quick healing. It is important to keep the bandage wet so treating it with ointment is the best solution. If someone has stopped breathing, firm pats on the back or head might help if they are choking. If someone's heart has stopped the patient is dead.

Advanced healing and surgery
This page will deal with advanced healing and surgery procedures.

Advanced healing has to do with more serious injuries. The kinds of unseen injury include: broken bones, internal bleeding, organ failure, and blood on the brain. To treat broken bones, first you must identify the kind of break: simple fracture, compound fracture, displaced fractures, non-displaced fracture. A simple fracture is a slight crack but does not completely break bone. A compound break is where the bone breaks and pokes through the skin. A displaced fracture is where the bone splits into many parts, and a non-displaced fracture is where the bone completely breaks but doesn't move. For non-displaced and simple the treatment is support of bone and direct pressure (direct pressure is on the bone itself, vertical pressure is not advised). For compound and displaced fractures surgery is needed to correct the bone placement. Make sure to get splinters and chips out of the wound before correction.
To check for internal bleeding the best way is to feel and look for bloating and discomfort and vomiting blood. Treatment is surgery.
Organ failure and blood on the brain are for surgeons only. Organ failure is detected by humour testing and assessments, you should look for serious signs before surgery such as septic blood and severe illness. Blood on the brain causes headaches, blurred vision, and personality changes. Only treatment is drilling the skull to relieve pressure.
Surgery procedures: First sedate patient and numb area. It may be needed to explain what you are going to do if patient is awake. Next plan exactly what you are going to do and follow through accordingly. Lastly, close up any incisions made and bandage.

Ethics
This section will explain about ethics of medicine and the Hippocratic oath.

It is important to realize that as a healer you literally have life in your palms. It is ok to make mistakes but with such an important subject as life, mistakes are lethal. First point of ethics is to never lie to a patient. It is a fine line to walk, if a patient is critically injured and asks "How am I.", the truth could trigger panic or shock so it is best to be vague. Notice I say vague not lie. Another good point in lying to patients is if dealing with stubborn or difficult people. It may seem easier to just lie when diagnosing or medicating but it can lead to harmful situations, the biggest being lost of trust. If people don't trust you to heal them what good are you as a healer? The last bit I want to discuss about ethics is code of conduct and privacy. You as a healer can turn no one down nor force people to get healed. The big issue here is even if you hate somebody it is your duty as a healer to see that they are healthy. The only exception is if someone is blacklisted from the infirmary (usually for violence towards healers) then you can refuse to treat them in the infirmary.
Following is the Hippocratic oath:
I swear to fulfill, to the best of my ability and judgment, this covenant: I will respect the hard-won scientific gains of those physicians in whose steps I walk, and gladly share such knowledge as is mine with those who are to follow. I will apply, for the benefit of the sick, all measures [that] are required, avoiding those twin traps of over treatment and therapeutic nihilism. I will remember that there is art to medicine as well as science, and that warmth, sympathy, and understanding may outweigh the surgeon's knife or the chemist's drug. I will not be ashamed to say "I know not", nor will I fail to call in my colleagues when the skills of another are needed for a patient's recovery. I will respect the privacy of my patients, for their problems are not disclosed to me that the world may know. Most especially must I tread with care in matters of life and death. If it is given to me to save a life, all thanks. But it may also be within my power to take a life; this awesome responsibility must be faced with great humbleness and awareness of my own frailty. Above all, I must not play at God. I will remember that I do not treat a fever chart, a cancerous growth, but a sick person, whose illness may affect the their family and economic stability. My responsibility includes these related problems, if I am to care adequately for the sick. I will prevent disease whenever I can, for prevention is preferable to cure. I will remember that I remain a member of society with special obligations to all my fellow people, those sound of mind and body as well as the infirm. If I do not violate this oath, may I enjoy life and art, be respected while I live and remembered with affection thereafter. May I always act so as to preserve the finest traditions of my calling and may I long experience the joy of healing those who seek my help.
Humorology
This section will deal with all things humorology. Including: definition, testing, and diagnosis.

Humourology is the the study of humours. Humours are the bodily fluids that keep a person healthy and balance. These humours are split into four categories and associate with elements. Blood(air), yellow bile (fire), black bile (earth) , and phlegm (water). If one is unbalanced, either with excess or depletion, one will be ill or diseased.
The testing of one's humour should be done indoors with these tools: water, rock, and a candle. In essence you need to test the humor with the element associated with it. To test blood you have the patient hold a candle and watch the smoke. To test the yellow bile have the patient hold a candle and watch the flame. To test the black bile have the patient hold a rock. To test the phlegm pour water on the patient and watch the way the water falls.
To diagnose the patient simply apply your finding from the testing. (ooc for testing I suggest having the patient @roll four times, unless you know what is wrong with the patient and want to apply a humour to it. If they roll 1-4 they are low in that humour, 5-8 they are normal in that humour, and 9-12 they are high in the humour).
Blood- If the smoke from the candle was invisible then the patient has depleted their blood humour. Oppositely if the smoke from the candle is heavy and swirls around the patient their blood humour is excessive. To treat a low balanced blood humour, have the patient eat red meat, fruity drinks, or have them smoke a cigar at dawn while facing the sun. If the blood humour is excessive have the patient bled.
Yellow bile- If the the flame from the candle is barely seen and doesn't move the yellow bile is depleted. If the flame is huge and dances wildly, the patient has excessive yellow bile. To treat a low balanced yellow bile have the patient drink a cup of ale, eat a piece of bread, or sleep on their stomach for a week. If the yellow bile is excessive then have the patient drink water, fast for three days, or kneel on grass at dawn facing away from the sun.
Black bile- If the rock is cold to the touch after five minutes of holding the black bile is low. If the rock is hotter then the skin of the patient after five minutes of holding it the black bile is high. To treat low black bile have the patient eat a vegetable, drink a cup of saffron tea, or hold dirt in their palm every day at noon for thirty minutes. To treat high black bile have the patient eat a bug, drink mint tea, or sleep on their back for a week.
Phlegm- If the water travels in a straight line their phlegm is depleted. If the water splits into two rivulets the phlegm is excessive. To treat depleted phlegm have the patient drink three cups of water, sleep an extra hour, or float in the bay every morning for ten minutes. If the phlegm is excessive have the patient smoke a cigar, sleep by the fire, or drink a cup of cinnamon tea.

Equipment
This lists the equipment used and it's function.

Bandage- used for keeping open wounds dry and dirt free.
scissors- used to cut cloth into bandages and to cut surgical thread.
sewing needle -used to sew fabric or to pop blisters.
Stitching needle- used to sew flesh only.
scalpel-used to make incisions in flesh.
tweezers- used to pinch small objects.
surgical thread - used to keep wounds closed for faster healing.
surgical kit- used to hold supplies and equipment.
tray- used to hold equipment in a safe spot.
bowl- used to hold discards such as dead flesh ect.
towel- used for cleansing purposes.
soap- used for cleansing purposes.
water- used for cleansing purposes.
mortar and pestle- used for grinding raw herbs into medicine.
candle- used for cauterizing.
dagger- used for cauterizing.
bonesaw- used for amputation.
blunt hook- used for probes for dissection and for raising blood vessels
sharp hook- used to hold and lift small pieces of tissue so that they could be extracted, and to retract the edges of wounds.
bone forceps- used to extract bone pieces that can't be grasped with fingers. The edges are serrated to help clamp down.
bone lever- used to move bones and secure them in place.
spatula probe- used to mix and apply various ointments to patients.
surgical scissors- used to hold wounds open or blood veins closed. Can also cut through tough tissue.
trephine- used to drill holes into thick bone such as skulls.
